newsitem.title: ZAIRE: Ugandan troops hand border town to Zairean rebels.
newsitem.headline: Ugandan troops hand border town to Zairean rebels.

text.p: Ugandan troops who occupied parts of eastern Zaire for the past two weeks have withdrawn, leaving Zairean Banyamulenge rebels to run the key border town of Kasindi, officials said on Monday.
"We have pulled everyone out now... The Banyamulenge are in charge over there," said Captain Peter Magara at Bwera, the small town on the Ugandan side of the border.
Uganda said its troops crossed the border to drive out Ugandan rebels who were attacking from inside Zaire. It says they have now accomplished this task.
The Zairean rebels have the sympathy of the Ugandan government and are hostile towards the Ugandan rebels.

On Monday a force of around 50 Zairean rebels was guarding the deserted border town. Vehicles crossed from Uganda for the first time in two weeks and headed for Beni, about 75 km (45 miles) away. Beni fell to the Banyamulenge last week.
"The road to Beni is secured," said one of the Banyamulenge rebels. "The area is clear and it is now safe to drive through."
